user.biography: This is the official Instagram for Grand Teton National Park. Use #MyGrandTeton for a chance to be featured. Top 10 tips for visiting the park:

node.text:
Grand Teton National Park has experienced many wonderful things this decade, thanks for spending the past 10 years with us! We cannot wait to see what the next decade brings.
#mygrandteton #findyourpark #encuentratuparque

node.title: Grand Teton National Park: A Look Over the Past Decade

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 14, 2021. May be an image of nature, twilight, sky, tree and mountain.

node.text:
There is something special about the simplicity of natural rhythms. 

In Grand Teton, you may find the morning call of white-crowned sparrows, the ripening of huckleberries, or an afternoon thunderstorm over the peaks. It may be as simple as the sun setting behind the mountains each day. 

How can we find peace in these natural rhythms?

#MyGrandTeton #FindYourPark #EncuentraTuParque

Photo courtesy of S. Textor

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 14, 2021. May be an image of nature and sky.

node.text:
The sun has to sleep sometime too!

All jokes aside, the Teton Sunset is truly a Graaaannd experience! Where have you seen your favorite sunset? Don't forget to share pictures with us!

Photo Courtesy N. Sherrod

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 13, 2021. May be an image of tree and nature.

node.text:
Earlier today a small fire was spotted off the Teton Park Road near the Potholes turnout. The fire is being suppressed by Teton Interagency Fire. The cause is being investigated and is likely natural.

However, this serves as a reminder that fire danger in the Grand Teton National Park and the surrounding area is high and visitors can help prevent more fires from starting. Campfires are limited to designated and installed fire rings. Campfires should always be attended to and must be completely “dead out” and cold to the touch before leaving a site.

NPS Photo/C. Collins

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 12, 2021. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
Dance like no one is watching . . . "

The Sandhill Crane (Antigone canadensis) has a very elaborate courtship "dance," with birds spreading wings, leaping in the air while calling their very distinctive call. 

Nest sites are established among marsh vegetation in shallow water (sometimes up to 3' deep) as well on dry ground close to water. 

Are there other wildlife in the Tetons that have unusual courtship rituals that you have witnessed?

Photo courtesy of/ P Petersen
Photo taken with a zoom lens

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 11, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'T - GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK'.

node.text:
Make a wish 🌠

…Or a hundred wishes! The Perseid meteor shower is here!

The Perseids will send shooting stars through the sky during the month of August, peaking on August 11th, 12th, and 13th. Follow these tips for experiencing the best meteor shower of the year:

⏰ Set your alarm clock ⏰ The early morning hours are when the most meteors will by flying through the atmosphere and the moon is below the horizon (moon sets at 10:32pm, 10:55pm, and 11:20pm, on August 11th, 12th, and 13th, respectively).

🙂 No equipment necessary 🙂 All you need is yourself—no binoculars, astronomical knowledge, or special equipment--just let your eyes adjust to the darkness for about 20 minutes. 

🌌 Find a dark, wide open sky 🌌 Find a dark place (like Grand Teton 😉) and a wide open area without any obstacles (i.e. trees) or lights for the best view! You may be able to see up to 50-100 meteors per hour during peak times. 

🪑 Make yourself comfy 🪑 The longer you stay out, the more you’ll see—so you might as well be comfortable! Bring blankets, chairs, hot cocoa, etc. to maximize your enjoyment.

🔺 Stay safe out there 🔺 Bring a friend, tell someone where you're going, and take a red light so your eyes can adjust but you don't trip finding your way to the perfect spot. If you’re in bear country, don’t forget your bear spray!

☁️ Shake off expectations ☁️ Meteors are a part of nature; their frequency can be unpredictable and so is the visibility of the night sky (cloud, smoke, light pollution, etc.) The best you can do is plan ahead and think clearing thoughts! Check the Fire and Smoke Map (https://fire.airnow.gov/) for air quality conditions, especially if you are in the Western U.S.

Grand Teton wishes you happy meteor watching!

#MyGrandTeton #FindYourPark #EncuentraTuParque
NPS Photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 10, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Have you seen this plant and wondered what it is?

Woodland Pinedrops (Pterospora andromedea) is an unusual plant in Grand Teton National Park. The tall rigid red stem has clusters of pendent egg shaped cream yellow flowers and no leaves.

Flowers forms around the red stem. They have five short red sepals and a rounded corolla that opens to five curved lobes.
 
The pumpkin-shaped fruit follows the flower stage that has tissue-like appendages underneath.  The woodland pinedrops flowers only once a season. The withered, brownish stems may remain upright for several years before falling.

Photo courtesy of/ BK Appleby

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 10, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Black bears and grizzly bears thrive in Grand Teton National Park and the John D. Rockefeller Jr. Memorial Parkway. You may encounter a bear anywhere at any time. 

With the warmer weather of summer, bears will be more often seen while hiking the trails of the Tetons as they seek the cooler shade of the forests and ripening berries. 

More information on being Bear Safe is found by visiting the following link;

https://www.nps.gov/grte/planyourvisit/bearsafety.htm

#bebearaware #blackbear #grizzlybear #bearspray 

Photo Courtesy of/ BK Appleby
Photo taken with zoom lens

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 10, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.

node.text:
Have you had a butterfly fly past you in the park? Chances are that it was an Aphrodite Fritillary butterfly!

Today we are taking a closer look at the Aphrodite Fritillary butterfly (Speyeria aphrodite). These particular butterflies tend to live longer than most other butterflies with a life span of approximately a year. They can be found in woodland areas and wet or dry habitats. 

The dorsal side of this butterfly displays the beautiful orange and slightly black patterned wingspan that it has, while the ventral sides, which are visible when the wings are closed, demonstrate similar orange coloration and some white dotting or speckling. 

What is one of your favorite butterfly species to see in the park?

#FindYourPark #EncuentraTuParque #MyGrandTeton 

Photo courtesy of M. Yang

node.accessibility_caption: An American pika sits on a boulder with a mouthful of plants

node.text:
Preparation is key!

The American pika’s ultimate summer goal is to prepare food for winter. They collect grasses, leaves, and flowers to dry out and store in haypiles for the long, cold months. Although they collect edible plants that they consume during early winter, they also collect plants that have high levels of toxins. Why? The toxins help preserve the plants for longer and eventually break down so that the plants are edible during late winter months.

Once their rocky homes are buried in snow, all their hard work from the summer pays off!

What goals are you working toward this summer?

#MyGrandTeton 

Photo courtesy of S. Textor

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on August 09, 2021. May be an image of tree, nature and sky.

node.text:
"Half the park happens after dark!" 

What is your favorite memory of viewing the Milky Way during the summertime?

Photo Courtesy/ Phil Petersen

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park in Grand Teton National Park. May be an image of tree, cloud and nature.

node.text:
Keep your eyes in the sky for any dark, ominous clouds looming over the Teton range during these summer months. Weather can quickly change from clear and sunny mornings to booming thunderclouds in the afternoon. Make sure you check the weather radar before going on your hike and carry raingear in your backpack. Consider turning around or seeking shelter when the sounds of thunder get closer and become more frequent.

#MyGrandTeton #FindYourPark #EncuentraTuParque #PlanLikeAParkRanger 

Photo Coutesy of E. Kim

node.text:
Bears love berries beary much!

Bears are excited for this time of the season because their favorite food is ripe for picking. Be aware of bears foraging nearby or on trails during your hike. You can also try some berries for a quick trail snack, but make sure you properly identify them due to the presence of many inedible look-alikes. Also leave enough for the bears to eat. Mother bears need to find enough bear necessities for their little ones.

Video courtesy of E. Kim

#FindYourPark #EncuentraTuParque #MyGrandTeton
